I learned this from gaming. Do a practice run without reviewing the materials, be comfortable with failing and learning from it. Then try again on your own to test out your theory, if you’re stumped look at whatever material you need. So I find for myself the best way to study or game is actually to fail on my own before I get help. Because if you look at the material before the “test” or game (you never played) you don’t really understand what’s going on. Go through it on your own first learn where you messed up and study on how to not make the same mistake. I find I learn a lot faster and retain information better this way.
This definitely wasn't an ad.

For sequential things like a piece of music or an athletic feat, getting the last bit down first and then gradually incorporating earlier sections helps to form a solid routine. It’s called backchaining. For instance, if you want to learn a song, you can practice getting the last stanza or phrase down first, then practice the second to last section to the end and so on. That way, the earlier sections become a cue for the next sections and you don’t get into the habit of practicing a part in the middle and then stopping because you don’t know the later part yet.

Also, it's much preferable to SLEEP after learning something. For example, if one did the split study sessions the day before a test, 3-4 hours in the morning, 3-4 hours in the evening, and a solid 8 hours of sleep overnight. They will have much better retention and recall compared to a person who stayed up late cramming for 6-8 straight and slept 4-6 hours, or especially someone who got up early and crammed for a few hours straight right before the test. Best of the best? Split study on T-2 days, then split study the day before, and you'll be able to recall things with as little difficulty as possible. It is remarkably noticeable. Try it! Also be sure to jot down vague notes during lectures. Don't write a verbatim lecture transcript for Christ's sake, just major concepts and important details. Hearing and seeing the lecture activates sensory pathways. Going further to write it down your own way (loosely, paraphrased, condensed) activates your cognitive frontal lobe areas much more, and it activates your motor cortex, your basal ganglia, and your cerebellum. That makes memory formation so much more likely.

I like the idea of a Google certificate.....the only problem is the employers aren't really looking for that lol. For example, if you want to get into I.T, you will be WAY better off going for a CompTIA certification than a Google one. Employers look for specific requirements and certifications, not board general ones lol. Besides, even Google themselves look for more specific certifications than broad general ones. For example, you have a better chance of landing an I.T job at Google with a CompTIA certification than you do a Google one, even though you'd be applying to Google!!! You have to remember that these giant companies are in it for the money and profits. If they can create a product that sells, they will do it. That doesn't mean it's the best product........and even the company making it knows that!! But they won't care if it sells. Just remember that and do extensive research before buying into something being pushed onto you!
